item.title: A Comprehensive Comparison of Basic Education in Spain: The Truth Chinese Parents Should Know
item.description:
Spain has a free and compulsory education system for ages 6 to 16, covering 6 years of primary school and 4 years of middle school.

üìö School Hours and Tuition Differences

  • Spanish Public Schools: School hours are from 9:00 AM to 2:00 PM, with 4 classes per day. It’s free.
  • Spanish Private and International Schools: School hours are typically from 9:00 AM to 4:00 PM, with 6 classes per day.
    • The median tuition for private schools is about ‚Ç¨6,000/year (approx. 50,000 RMB).
    • International schools are about ‚Ç¨8,000/year (approx. 70,000 RMB).
    • There are significant variations based on grade level, region, and school, with differences of 1-2 times the median.

üè´ Teaching Staff and Pedagogical Features

  • Teacher absenteeism is relatively high in Spain. A doctor’s note for sick leave is legally binding and can be issued over the phone for paid sick leave.
  • Primary school generally follows a “generalist” system, where one teacher teaches multiple subjects like English, math, humanities, science, art, and physical education, limiting subject-specific expertise.
  • Subject-specific teaching only begins in middle school.
  • The saying “the gym teacher teaches math” is not a joke in Spain but a result of the primary school generalist system.
  • Exam scores are not ranked.

üàØ Language of Instruction and Multilingual Environment

  • International schools primarily use English for instruction.
  • Private and public schools mainly use Spanish.
  • Autonomous communities like Valencia and Catalonia require the study of local languages.
  • A second foreign language, such as French or German, is introduced in middle school, making the multilingual workload heavy.

üìñ Workload and Holiday Schedule

  • Less homework after school.
  • The academic year is divided into three terms, with a total of about 160‚Äì180 teaching days.
  • Long holidays.

üá®üá≥ Comparison with Basic Education in China

  • Public Schools: School hours are from 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM, with 6‚Äì8 classes per day. It’s free, with some regions offering after-school programs.
  • Private/International Schools: 8:00 AM to 5:30 PM, with evening self-study sessions starting in middle school, which do not exist in Spain.
    • Private: Approx. 60,000 RMB/year
    • International: Approx. 180,000 RMB/year
  • The academic year is divided into two semesters, with over 190 teaching days.

üèüÔ∏è Campus Facility Gap

  • International schools in China often boast campuses of over 100 acres, featuring heated swimming pools, theaters, multimedia libraries, maker labs, Olympic-standard stadiums, and even equestrian fields, golf courses, and drone and robotics labs.
  • Spanish schools, in contrast, are modest and compact, with simple facilities.

item.title: The Ethnic Nature of the Han People: 5,000 Years of Huaxia Bloodline and Chinese Culture
item.description:
1. Mythical Beginnings: Yan, Huang, and Chiyou

As recorded in the Records of the Grand Historian and Discourses of the States:

  • The Yellow Emperor (Huangdi) defeated the Yan Emperor (Yandi) at the Battle of Banquan, causing the Yan tribe to submit to his rule.
  • He then defeated Chiyou at the Battle of Zhuolu, securing ultimate victory.

These are not merely legends but symbols of the integration of ancient tribes:

  • Yellow Emperor’s group: Agricultural tribes of the Central Plains, with the surname Ji.
  • Yan Emperor’s group: Tribes with the surname Jiang, related to the ancient Qiang people.
  • Chiyou’s group: The Jiuli (Nine Li) tribes, ancestors of the southern Miao-Man peoples.

Ultimately, the people of the Yan Emperor and Chiyou were incorporated into the Yellow Emperor’s tribe, forming the “Huaxia.”
